You can't polish a turd - gambling is gambling

text: I think it's something that we need to watch out for here as well. In particular I think we ought to be wary of encouraging people to keep trying if they're not making it work. I really don't want to be part of that dynamic.

text: I hear you <@UGV299K6H> but you have to acknowledge that there are some positives to betting via automation and analysis as compared with sitting on your arse in front of a monitor using someone else's software to stare at prices on a ladder for hours on end. At least you learn something doing it in an automated capacity. Yeah it's not worth losing thousands to get that experience of coding or stats or ML etc. but ther CAN be a lot more upside than from doing things manually.

That was me. Years of losses. Probably would still be in the same boat without TPD. I also spent months developing my own ladder trading app but that was not just for betting that was a genuine side project.
That said, had I found this slack years before I actually did I think I would have fared a lot better.
I think it's up to the individual to decide and I've no evidence to back it up but I'd say it's way way harder to get an addiction via automation. I

text: Automation is the antidote to problem gambling imo. Once you've found out how hard it is to find an edge using serious data/analysis etc it makes it virtually impossible to have a casual bet without seeing how futile that is.

text: I kind of have it, and in truth, I think that the affordability check stuff would help. I keep a larger (and fairly constant) bank than I really need, but if that disappears, I won't be depositing again. I'd like to think that if I even lost half of it I'd cash out but in truth would probable let it ride. I'd never get away with depositing the funds to claw that bank back.

text: How can you get wiped out with a glitch if you're managing your money? Eg 10k in the account, never expose more than about 2k.  That gives you 3 consecutive blue moon events and you're still in the game.  It's the people who lay down their whole bank expecting to 'trade out' who get stung.

text:
The basic scenario is that a trader might back £1 at 100 and then tries to lay £1 @ 90.

The risk should be £1, as maybe the price doesn't reach 90.

But if both are matched, there are edge cases (as <@UUE6E1LA1> mentioned above) where the back bet gets voided. So the risk is actually £90.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text:
The basic scenario is that a trader might back £1 at 100 and then tries to lay £1 @ 90.

The risk should be £1, as maybe the price doesn't reach 90.

But if both are matched, there are edge cases (as
mentioned above) where the back bet gets voided. So the risk is actually £90.

text:
In that example <@UPMUFSGCR> the risk was always £90 for that very reason. Tech is famously falable and it's naive to assume the worse case scenario won't occur, especially if you're betting 247.

But I'd hope not thinking about that risk adequately would be a one time error, and as such it might not be a reason to stop. Unless you do it twice.

elements.text: In that example

the risk was always £90 for that very reason. Tech is famously falable and it's naive to assume the worse case scenario won't occur, especially if you're betting 247.

But I'd hope not thinking about that risk adequately would be a one time error, and as such it might not be a reason to stop. Unless you do it twice.

text:
Well I guess I should comment as I posted the image..
My experience is that recent times are different than in previous times (ie 5-15 years ago), in previous times you could get matched easier and for larger stakes.
These days, there is usually at least one a day, I merely post them to show that they are happening. I would expect there to be at least one or two over the next couple of days. So we _know_ they will happen, but catching one is something completely different. (Although Liam did ok :money_mouth_face:)
I haven't checked all my accounts, but fairly certain I didn't get matched at high odds.
The thing that intrigued me about this one is that TPD was present and you may have thought that there was some indication, who knows.
I've always had an interest in these big priced winners...at what point does something become a 1000/1 shot?

This was one of the first wins for me :

<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hjb9EVY1S60>
I think i got matched for +£4
So to answer your question And, Yes there is value backing at 1000, but there is also value laying at 1000 too

(*edit: I may be wrong about the £4 matched on the above, I think it was on the 15:30 at Leicester 28 may 2013 )

text:
If it's value, it's value - be it back or lay. They always interest me because I don't have the risk appetite to lay at that price but often find myself backing them and always wonder who is on the other side of that transaction - particularly when you see a large amount matched. Often when the winner hits 1000 it's only pennies matched but sometimes you see a significant lump. Didn't  someone quite recently post one with over £200 matched?
Seeing that I've backed a winner at 1000 is one of the few things about automated trading that still gives me a bit of the old-fashioned "gambling buzz".
